DOC.HEAD: Construction Companies Pay in Bid-Rigging Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government is being paid $32.7 million by 99 Japanese companies to settle bid-rigging charges that officials say raised construction costs of a U.S. Navy base by 25 percent. The cartel of 140 companies had bid on construction of the base at Yokosuka, the Justice Department said Tuesday. Japan's Fair Trade Commission, which administers that country's antitrust laws, earlier had fined 69 companies 1.5 percent of the value of each company's contract, for a total of $2.2 million, and had warned 70 unsuccessful bidders not to continue in the bid-rigging arrangement. Some companies offered to negotiate a settlement as a result of threats of a U.S. government lawsuit in the Japanese courts and also in the U.S. courts against 26 companies also doing business in the United States, the department said. The settlement, which involved 99 firms, was negotiated in November, the agency said. Japanese construction companies frequently collaborate on bids in a system called ``dango'' where the bidders decide who gets the winning bid. The 140 companies bidding for U.S. Navy contracts at Yokosuka formed an association in 1984 that called itself ``Seiyukai,'' or ``Friends of the Stars,'' a reference to the American flag. The association dissolved in 1987 when the companies became aware that they were under investigation by the Navy. Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the civil division of the department, said the U.S. government would pursue ``available remedies,'' including possible lawsuits in Japan, the United States or both countries, against construction companies that did not join the settlement. ``We are pleased to have been able to reach a just result through the Japanese legal process,'' Gerson said.
